An Aerospace Aftercare Use Case
Simplified version of Lost Waxs use case (previous presentation) Aircraft engine manufacturers:
I Need to maintain an operational engine pool I Receive hourly rates for engine usage I Need to provide minimum service levels
Electronic contracts established between manufacturers and airlines
F. Meneguzzi (Kings College London) Electronic contracting in aircraft aftercare AAMAS 2008 3 / 21
Aftercare contracts
Complex agreements Include provisions for:
I Restricting provenance of engines I Specifying a minimum number of spare engines I Maximum idle time for aircraft waiting maintenance I Penalties for violations

Background on Electronic Contracting
Systems of self-interested agents: I Inherently unreliable I Require societal control
We use norms to regulate agent behaviour: I Ensure compliance with societal goals I Usually expressed using deontic concepts
Norms incorporated into a formal document Contract

The CONTRACT Project
Explore multiple aspects of contract-based systems Aiming at an electronic contracting framework:
I Facilitates design, enactment and management of contracts I Includes critical aspects of a contract life cycle I Instantiated here for aerospace aftercare

Contract Parties
Business contract parties: I Agents targeted by the contract I Obligations largely concerned with business objectives
Administrative contract parties: I Required to maintain system integrity:
F Observer monitors critical state F Manager responds to notifications by observer

AgentSpeak(L) and Jason
AgentSpeak(L) is a procedural agent language Based on the BDI model Designer specifies plans in a library:
I Plans encode procedures I Plans are characterised by trigger and context conditions I Goals are implicit in the plans
Lends itself well to state-based monitoring mechanism Prototype implementation in the Java-based Jason
